instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stuck on 5v liquid damage
threads.message:
A <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> came in with liquid damage, alot of it. Tried cleaning the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> and ISL but no luck. Removed both CD3215s after seeing brown/black goo coming from underneath it, but after replacing still no luck.

Have not worked with USB-C macbooks before so one thing is not completely clear. Is it true that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> need <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to function and, the CD3215s need the PP3v3 voltage line to make 5v into 20 volts? Does this mean that I start with the PPBUS short and after that start solving the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> problem?

If my reasoning is bad I apologise, I wanted to show my thought process to make it easier to see when I am going wrong.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stuck on 5v liquid damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> MUST appear first, with 5V input.
Once SMC boots, will talk with <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips, to switch input to 20V.
It will also tell to <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> when to generate <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

Post diode mode to ground for the 4 LDO outputs of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stuck on 5v liquid damage
threads.message:
4 outputs of L3200
1 - 645
2 - 645
3 - 1507
4 - 1507

couldnt find another LDO connected to the other <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, not experienced with these boards Im sorry

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stuck on 5v liquid damage
threads.message:
Each <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> has 4 (four) LDO rails:
- 1x 3V3.
- 2x 1V8,
- 1x 1V1.
Consult schematic, look inside <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> block notations.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stuck on 5v liquid damage
threads.message:
Jep found em!

<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0V (diode mode 540)
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 1.77V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 1.80V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> = 3.35V

<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0V (diode mode OL)
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 1.78V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 1.80V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> = 3.35V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stuck on 5v liquid damage
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 0V (diode mode OL)"
There should be a bad solder; you must get similar diode mode reading as the other chip.
I hope you've measured both chips with red probe to ground.

BTW, 1V1 LDO voltage should appear only on the powered port.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stuck on 5v liquid damage
threads.message:
diode mode fixed
measured <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R3001</RESISTOR> and it's there
you mentioned the 3V3 rail should start with input 5V is that correct?
I see alot of bidirectional datalines on the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s, what output line(s) can I check to know it's working to a large extent? which are the last ones to come on?

<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 540
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 500
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 600
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> = OL

<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 540
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 1850
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 1900
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> = OL

Is this an indication that the B chip is badly soldered? Since some the diodemode readings are relatively high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stuck on 5v liquid damage
threads.message:
You can't get OL on any LDO rail.
Be sure to check (ALWAYS) diode mode with red probe connected to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stuck on 5v liquid damage
threads.message:

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 490
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 550
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> = 530

<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> = 570
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> = 520
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> = 570

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stuck on 5v liquid damage
threads.message:
The values are bit higher.
But this could be caused by bad chip, or bad solders.
Can be even normal difference.
Did you solder same CD3215C00 chip?

I bet for more damage caused by liquid spill.
<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> and surrounding components, look clean?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stuck on 5v liquid damage
threads.message: <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> does look quite dirty. Cleaned with alcohol and did a reflow, but the diode number dont seem to change much from earlier. These are CD3215s from the same IC strip. bad solder could be the culprit, would you advice to put on 2 new CD3215s or first rule out other problems? Maybe when removing CD3215s checking underneath the IC could uncover some damaged traces? The solder points when I put em on seemed fine for both at the first replacement

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stuck on 5v liquid damage
threads.message:
<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> is not related with diode mode readings on <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
But these chips need to read information from TBT ROM.
If any pull-up resistor is bad, or other surrounding components, board cannot switch to 20V.

Liquid could also affected Thunderbolt controller (<CHIP>U2800</CHIP>), which is directly connected with both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stuck on 5v liquid damage
threads.message:
couldnt find any out of the ordinary resistor reading as in no bad pull-up resistors

at <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> the lower right resistors are affected by liquid damage: <RESISTOR>R3097</RESISTOR> <RESISTOR>R3094</RESISTOR> <RESISTOR>R2829</RESISTOR>, replacing those right now

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> stuck on 5v liquid damage
threads.message:
Something else corroded.
Could be trace, solder, or component...
